description: Possibly from the same roots as snug (“to lie close”).

examples: Kevin finally got to snog his girlfriend and fool around once his roommates went to bed.

verbs.description: snog (third-person singular simple present snogs, present participle snogging, simple past and past participle snogged)

examples: This is about stepping up and representing, not snuggling up and snogging. This is serious business.
